Taylor approximation and Laplace's method

Ville Karhunen

03.11.2024

taylorlaplace.Rmd

Consider the scenario where we want to evaluate the marginal likelihood of the data, that is, the integral

πm(D)=∫π(β̂|βm)πβ(βm)dβm=∫e−f(βm)dβm. \pi_{m}(D) = \int \pi(\hat{\beta}|\beta_{m})\pi_{\beta}(\beta_m)d\beta_{m} = \int e^{-f(\beta_{m})}d\beta_{m}.

The subscript mm refers to a specific model (or causal configuration), and we drop this index from further notation for simplicity. A second order Taylor approximation of ff at β0\beta_0 is:

π(D)≈∫e−(f(β0)+(β−β0)f′(β0)+12(β−β0)2f″(β0))dβ \pi(D) \approx \int e^{-(f(\beta_0) + (\beta - \beta_{0})f'(\beta_0) + \frac{1}{2}(\beta - \beta_{0})^2f''(\beta_0))}d\beta

The standard Laplace’s method would use the global maximum of ff as β0\beta_0, in which case f′(β0)=0f'(\beta_0) = 0 and the first order term of the approximation vanishes. However, this requires optimising ff, which can be costly.

Alternatively, we can apply approximate Laplace’s approximation (Rossell et al. 2021) to evaluate the Taylor approximation at some β0\beta_0, which is not necessarily the global maximum. Note that as β\beta is small, we can safely assume that this point will be in the vicinity of the global maximum.

Let’s consider an example with β̂=0.049\hat{\beta} = 0.049 and SE(β̂)=0.007\text{SE}(\hat{\beta}) = 0.007:

library(finimom)

betahat <- 0.049
sebetahat <- 0.007

xx <- seq(-0.2, 0.2, length.out = 200)

f <- function(x, beta, se, r = 1, tau = 0.0083){ log(dimom(x, r = r, tau = tau)) + dnorm(x, beta, se, log = TRUE)}
y <- f(xx, beta = betahat, se = sebetahat)
plot(xx, y, type = "l")

Let’s now construct the functions needed for the Taylor approximation:


gradient <- function(x, beta, se, r = 1, tau = 0.0083){ -1*((r + 1)/x - 2*tau/x^3 + x/se^2 - beta/se^2) }

hessian <- function(x, se, r = 1, tau = 0.0083){ -1*(6*tau/x^4 - (r + 1)/x^2 + 1/se^2)}

fval <- function(x, x0, beta, se){ (f(x0, beta = beta, se = se) +
                                      gradient(x0, beta = beta, se = se)*(x - x0) +
                                      0.5*(x - x0)^2*hessian(x0, se = se)) }
fval_laplace <- function(x, x0, beta, se){ (f(x0, beta = beta, se = se) - 0.5*(x - x0)^2*abs(hessian(x0, se = se))) }

Optimization for Laplace approximation:

opt <- optim(betahat, f, beta = betahat, se = sebetahat, method = "Nelder-Mead", control = list(fnscale = -1, warn.1d.NelderMead = FALSE))
opt$par
#> [1] 0.05269893

The curves of the true ff and its approxmations:


xf <- sapply(xx, fval_laplace, x0 = opt$par, beta = betahat, se = sebetahat)
xf_ala <- sapply(xx, fval, x0 = betahat, beta = betahat, se = sebetahat)

plot(xx, y, type = "l")
lines(xx, xf, lty = 2)
lines(xx, xf_ala, lty = 3)

When evaluating the value of the full integral, Laplace’s method gives us

π(D)≈e−f(β̃)(2π)P/2|Hβ̃|−1/2, \pi(D) \approx e^{-f(\tilde{\beta})}(2\pi)^{P/2}|H_{\tilde{\beta}}|^{-1/2},

where β̃\tilde{\beta} is the global maximum of ff, and Hβ̃H_{\tilde{\beta}} is the Hessian of ff evaluated at β̃\tilde{\beta}.

In contrast, the approximate Laplace approximates the integral by

π(D)≈e−f(β0)+12gβ0THβ0gβ0(2π)P/2|Hβ0|−1/2, \pi(D) \approx e^{-f(\beta_0) + \frac{1}{2}g_{\beta_0}^TH_{\beta_0}g_{\beta_0}}(2\pi)^{P/2}|H_{\beta_0}|^{-1/2},

where gβ0g_{\beta_0} and Hβ0H_{\beta_0} are the gradient and Hessian of ff, respectively, evaluated at β0\beta_0.

The downside of using the latter is that when computing the gradient gg, we have to invert the linkage disequilibrium matrix RR. However, this is still much faster than the optimisation of ff.
